episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of historical and quirky topics, including a humorous misunderstanding about a 1910 anti-kissing campaign, the bizarre post-execution treatment of King Charles I, a Finnish soldier's meth-fueled escape during World War II, and the logistics behind the queue for Queen Elizabeth II's lying in state.

facts.fact: In 1910, the World Health Organization tried to ban kissing.
After King Charles I was decapitated, he was recapitated.
In World War II, a Finnish soldier got tired in the Arctic, so took the entire platoon's rations of methamphetamine and subsequently skied 400 kilometers to safety.
The crowd science expert who designed and mapped out the queue is called Professor Keith Still.
